title: 113_hr3556
content: The Act titled "Humane Care for Primates Act of 2013" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 contains findings related to the Act. The Congress finds that nonhuman primates often face abusive conditions in other countries and may be subjected to inhumane deaths if suitable alternatives are not provided. Regulations only allow importation for scientific, educational, or exhibition purposes, not for lifetime shelter in sanctuaries. Certified primate sanctuaries in the United States could provide shelter and care for these animals for the remainder of their lives. Certified primate sanctuaries in the United States could provide shelter and care for nonhuman primates for the remainder of their natural lives in a species-appropriate, humane environment if allowed by law. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "certified primate sanctuary" refers to a facility certified by the Secretary, "nonhuman primates" are species in the order Primates excluding Homo sapiens, and a "primate sanctuary" rescues and cares for abused animals, is a tax-exempt organization, and does not trade animals commercially. A certified primate sanctuary must adhere to specific guidelines, including restrictions on breeding nonhuman primates, public contact, unescorted visitation, animal removal for exhibition, and conducting research on animals. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. SEC. 4. IMPORTATION OF NONHUMAN PRIMATES. The Secretary must revise regulations to allow importation of nonhuman primates by certified sanctuaries for lifetime shelter and care within 12 months of this Act. Certification process for primate sanctuaries will be established with specific criteria. The Secretary will require primate sanctuaries seeking certification to meet specific criteria and submit an application for protection of information.
